data.title: Adopt ext host configuration to use config data tree
data.body:
[Core configuration](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/platform/configuration/common/configuration.ts#L27) now exports configuration as [Configuration tree data](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/platform/configuration/common/configuration.ts#L198) from which [Configuration](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/platform/configuration/common/configuration.ts#L205) can be constructed.

This configuration object knows how to retrieve configuration. This is the object used in core and now can be reused in ext host. This will let ext host to support getting configuration for language overrides and multi root.

data.title: Git conflict code actions should work independently from editor.codeLens option
data.body: I usually have codelens turned off but I think the git merge tooling we have should always force to show them independent from this setting because here we are not talking about a language decoration but making the git merge tool more usable.

data.title: Conflict resolver does not support conflict style "diff3"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:18:03.540Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-79-generic
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|rainbow-brackets|2gua|0.0.6|
|ng-template|Angular|0.1.3|
|EditorConfig|EditorConfig|0.9.3|
|cucumberautocomplete|alexkrechik|2.3.0|
|gitlens|eamodio|4.1.1|
|tslint|eg2|0.15.0|
|vscode-great-icons|emmanuelbeziat|2.1.7|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.4|
|indent-rainbow|oderwat|0.6.1|
|vscode-jscpd|paulhoughton|0.2.0|
|postal|postal-team|1.0.0|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.9.0|
|stylelint|shinnn|0.24.8|
|code-spell-checker|streetsidesoftware|1.2.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. run command `git config --global merge.conflictstyle diff3`
2. create a conflict with git merge (or rebase or am or cherry-picking)
3. in vscode, conflict is displayed with 3 sections (<<<<<<< ours ||||||| original ======= theirs >>>>>>>)
4. if you click `Accept Current Changes`, both `ours` and `original` sections are included
5. or if you click `Accept Both Changes`, all sections are included (ours, original, theirs)
6. or if you click `Compare Changes`, left pane of comparison view contains both `ours` and `original` sections.

data.title: Observable pattern
data.body:
I would like to start a discussion about the usability of `PPromise` and potential alternatives.

**Motivation**

I have two open PRs (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/27886, https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/28751) that move in the direction of streaming data. I found `PPromise` to be a bit clunky to use for a few reasons including (but not limited to):

- When "upgrading" functions to return a PPromise instead of TPromise, it is inconvenient to differentiate between the final result and intermediate progress results. Usually when progress results are sent, you want to ignore the final result, but for backward compatibility with TPromise (if you don't want to make a sweeping change everywhere) you need to return a final result too.
- Non-standard behavior like [this](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/27886/files#diff-9c7cbde8051f3e7fdaf7cdd3765639fbR203) and [this](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/28751/files#diff-4c59e8f28d0ce535d7a6c667deba99a7R219).

There is also a [separate discussion](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/22318#issuecomment-305569385) regarding cancellation semantics.

**Proposal**

It would be nice if VSCode had a construct that represented a stream of results that could be transformed in a pipeline like fashion.

If the VSCode team is agreeable with this idea then there are at least three possible paths forward:
1. Import [RxJS](https://github.com/Reactive-Extensions/RxJS)
2. Polyfill or copy [ECMAScript's draft spec for Observable](https://github.com/tc39/proposal-observable/blob/master/src/Observable.js)
3. Implement the bare minimum concept of Observable that would be useful inside of VSCode.

I would be interested to know the VSCode team's thoughts on (1) the overall idea of having a replacement for PPromise and (2) which path forward would you favor.

Thanks!

data.title: Ctrl + Down doesn't keep cursor in viewport
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Those who are used to Visual Studio will be disoriented with this behavior. When you're using ctrl + down to move in the file, the cursor position will stay the same even when it goes out of view. So when you press any of the arrow keys after the scroll, the viewport will jarringly jump to the initial cursor's position.

The behavior we're used to in Visual Studio will keep the cursor in the viewport whenever possible (the cursor would stick to the first line in the viewport while going down), which I believe is the better behavior. Can't there be at least an option to switch between the 2 behaviors?

data.title: CTRL Alt Arrow Down Fails to Handle Virtual Space & Inability to Decreases A Selection.
data.body:
Two issues here, handling of virtual space and then the inability to reverse any selection.

**Steps**

1. Take any block of code which has space above and below it (blank lines with virtual space).

2. Doing <keyboard>CTRL</keyboard>+<keyboard>Alt</keyboard> + <keyboard>Arrow Down</keyboard> select from the middle towards and over the blank line below it to the next area.

_Notice how it puts the selection highlight at the first character instead of through **virtual** white space._

3. Now go up, it doesn't backtrack, it skips to the first highlight line and moves into the blank line.

_Notice how a selection is above the starting selection line, again also not in virtual white space._

_Also notice how up or down only adds to the selection, never decreases the selection._

![verticaledit edit](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1110966/27196368-63f55ab8-51c7-11e7-9671-349922c8bf56.gif)



[Test2.txt](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/1078625/Test2.txt)

data.title: EACCES: permission denied, doesn't open modal asking for user/pass
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.16|
|vscode-multi-line-tricks|bigous|0.0.3|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.5|
|vscode-babel-coloring|dzannotti|0.0.4|
|diff-tool|jinsihou|0.0.1|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.62|
|terraform|mauve|0.0.16|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.4|
|shellcheck|timonwong|0.1.0|
|vscode-proto3|zxh404|0.1.1|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run command to edit a file not owned by the current user, like `code /etc/hosts`
2. Save the file
3. See error
> Failed to save 'hosts': A system error occured (EACCES: permission denied, open '/private/etc/hosts')

Previously, VS Code seemed to handle this scenario properly by opening a window asking for admin user/password to escalate the save command. If I'm incorrect, apologies. The only other issues I see on this have proposed solutions that involve changing the owner of the files, which is not a correct fix, particularly in this scenario.

data.title: New Emmet completes html attribute as tag
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (fda3ed38449fea27b97698ad0950c2870bf6afaa, 2017-06-14T05:06:38.644Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|ng-template|Angular|0.1.3|
|vscode-markdownlint|DavidAnson|0.9.1|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.8.1|
|sort-lines|Tyriar|1.3.0|
|Bookmarks|alefragnani|0.15.1|
|project-manager|alefragnani|0.18.0|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|vscode-html-css|ecmel|0.1.7|
|tslint|eg2|0.15.0|
|auto-rename-tag|formulahendry|0.0.12|
|Angular2|johnpapa|2.3.3|
|theme-karyfoundation-themes|karyfoundation|14.0.0|
|HTMLHint|mkaufman|0.3.3|
|vscode-stylefmt|mrmlnc|2.4.1|
|angular2-inline|natewallace|0.0.17|
|vscode-code-outline|patrys|0.0.6|
|stylelint|shinnn|0.24.8|
|darcula-extended|smlombardi|3.3.2|
|slime|smlombardi|2.6.6|
|theme-tesla|smlombardi|6.0.0|
|change-case|wmaurer|1.0.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Take a piece of html like ` <select class="form-control focus">`
2. At the end, after the `class` try to add an `id` by typing `id`.  Intellisense shows 2 `id` entries.
3. Take the default.
4. You wind up with ` <select class="form-control focus" <id></id>>`

This is obviously incorrect.

Since AFAIK there is no html `<id></id>` tag, why is this even a completion?  And, even if you want to preserve that completion as an option, shouldn't Code default to the second Intellisense hint, the correct completion of `id=""`?

I would further suggest that tags should not be offered as completions when you're already inside a tag.

![jun-15-2017 13-44-56](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/835148/27194662-6ec5aae2-51d1-11e7-98fa-3d96cc0eb043.gif)

data.title: Find-all-references preview broken in insiders
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0-insider
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18

Steps to Reproduce:

Type:
```ts
function f() {}
// Put a lot of blank lines here. Or put it in a different file.
f();
```

1. Find-all-references for `f` in `function f() {}`
2. Click on the second result (the call `f();`)
3. I expect to see a preview of the use. Instead I am still looking at `function f() {}`. This does not happen in vscode 1.13.1.
